headline.main: Joe Camel, the Marlboro Man And the Cynical Art of Denial

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews, Tobacco Wars, Learning Channel documentary series on tobacco industry (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: By now few viewers can be astonished to learn that cigarette makers have not been models of candor when it comes to their products' effects on the health of their customers. But a little recapitulation can't hurt, and ''Tobacco Wars,'' which begins tonight on The Learning Channel, is a forceful reminder of an industry's half-century of efforts to obscure, obfuscate and delude. After a brief reminder by a former researcher for Philip Morris of the lure of nicotine and the efficiency of the cigarette as ''a drug delivery device,'' the three-part documentary moves briskly into the marketing and advertising techniques that helped propel tobacco into a $200 billion business. The old advertisements add a touch of nostalgia to the program's grim indictment.

headline.main: Producer Prices Show Gain of 1.1 Percent, Biggest in Nine Years

docs.lead_paragraph: Prices at the producer level shot up 1.1 percent in September, the biggest monthly increase in nine years, the Government reported today. The report stoked fears among investors that inflation might be accelerating and helped to set off a wave of selling on Wall Street, which was already jittery over comments on Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, about the difficulty of determining whether stock prices are too high.
